thread.title: Used car dealer sentenced for not turning over sales taxes
thread.title_full: Used car dealer sentenced for not turning over sales taxes

title: Used car dealer sentenced for not turning over sales taxes
text:
Used car dealer gets prison term for failing to turn over more than $156,000 in sales taxes 
THE ASSOCIATED PRESS Published: 10/17/15 2:09 pm EDT - Updated: 10/17/15 2:09 pm EDT 
TRENTON, New Jersey â€” A used car dealer who purposely failed to turn over more than $156,000 in state sales taxes has been sentenced to three years in prison, according to state authorities. 
Gennaro Dicecilia was also ordered Friday to pay the state $220,797 in restitution. 
The 58-year-old Toms River resident owns Automotion LLC, a dealership on Route 9 in Toms River. He admitted in July that he didn't turn over $156,564 in sales taxes he collected from customers. 
His actions came to light following a routine canvas of used car dealerships in Ocean County by the state's Division of Taxation in November 2011. The agency was seeking to identify dealerships that were not properly registered or licensed. 
During the canvas, it was determined Dicecilia had not filed any sales tax returns or remitted any sales tax since his dealership opened in 2007. 
Tax officials sought payment of the outstanding sales taxes, and Dicecilia subsequently filed sales tax returns. 
However, an audit by the tax division revealed that he deliberately hid information about the number of cars sold and the sales tax that he collected. 
Further investigation, based on vehicle title transfer records kept by the state's Motor Vehicle Commission, determined Dicecilia had collected $205,157 in sales tax but remitted only $48,593 during the civil audit.
